title: Get the suite CA certificate
content:
The steps to get the suite CA certificate are different depending on whether you have installed a complete certificate chain in the suite or in an external load balancer used for the suite.

We recommend that you install a complete certificate chain in a production environment. A properly configured suite should send all intermediate certificates to the client. For more information, see Replace the suite certificate.

Using an incomplete certificate chain isn't good in production and is a common misconfiguration that causes an "unable to get local issuer certificate" or "unable to find valid certification path to requested target" error during an SSL/TLS handshake between the client and server. The certificate chain can't be verified back to a local issuer certificate (which means it's in the client's certificate store). 

Note If you're unsure whether you have a complete certificate chain or not:
  • You can use the procedure of scenario 2 as it also works for scenario 1.
  • (Only if the suite system is public) You can also check the suite certificate by using Qualys' SSL Server Test. If the tool reports "This server's certificate chain is incomplete.", it means you must use the steps for scenario  2. However, this method requires your suite to be reachable from the internet.

Scenario 1 (recommended)

In this scenario, you have a complete certificate chain installed, either on an external load balancer or directly in the suite if you don't use an external load balancer. This is the recommended scenario.

In this scenario, obtaining the root CA certificate of the suite is good enough.

As an example, the following are the steps in Google Chrome to obtain the root CA certificate:

  1. Open the suite URL from a web browser: https://<External_Access_Host>:443.
  2. Click the lock icon before the URL on the address bar.
  3. Click Connection is secure
  4. Click Certificate is valid.
  5. On the Certification Viewer, click Details.
  6. In the Certificate Hierarchy, select the site root certificate (the topmost one), and then click Export. 
  7. Select the Base-64 encoded ASCII, single certificate format, and click Save.

Scenario 2

In this scenario, you have an incomplete certificate chain installed. This means you installed the server certificate only, either on an external load balancer or directly in the suite if you don't use an external load balancer. 

As an example, the following are the steps in Google Chrome to obtain the suite CA certificate chain (excluding the server certificate, which isn't required):

  1. Open the suite URL from a web browser: https://<External_Access_Host>:443.
  2. Click the lock icon before the URL on the address bar.
  3. Click Connection is secure.
  4. Click Certificate is valid.
  5. On the Certification Viewer, click Details to see the certificate chain.

    The following figure shows an example.

    In this example, as with many certificates nowadays, the suite certificate is signed by one or more CAs, also known as a "chained root". The topmost CA is the root, and any CAs under the root are known as intermediate CAs. We need the two topmost items, DigiCert Global Root CA and DigiCert TLS RSA SHA256 2020 CA1. These are the CAs we need to export from the suite and import into the integration endpoints. 

  6. Select the bottom CA in the chain (in this example, select DigiCert TLS RSA SHA256 2020 CA1) and click Export. 
  7. Select the Base-64 encoded ASCII, certificate chain format, and click Save. (Note that the bottom one in the certificate chain is the actual server certificate, which you don't need to export. )
